t: Song of Solomon 2
She
I*pn am a rose of Sharon, a*ld lily of the valleys.
He
Like*pn a lily among thorns is*ld my darling among the young women.
She
Like*pn an apple tree among the trees of the forest is*ld my beloved among the young men. I*ln delight to sit in his shade, and*ld his fruit is sweet to my taste.
Let*ln him lead me to the banquet hall, and*ld let his banner over me be love.
Strengthen*ln me with raisins, refresh*ld me with apples, for*ld I am faint with love.
His*ln left arm is under my head, and*ld his right arm embraces me.
Daughters*ln of Jerusalem, I charge you by*ld the gazelles and by the does of the field: Do*ln not arouse or awaken love until*ld it so desires.
Listen!*pn My beloved! Look!*ld Here he comes, leaping*ln across the mountains, bounding*ld over the hills.
My*ln beloved is like a gazelle or a young stag. Look!*ld There he stands behind our wall, gazing*ln through the windows, peering*ld through the lattice.
My*ln beloved spoke and said to me, “Arise,*ld my darling, my*ld beautiful one, come with me.
See!*ln The winter is past; the*ld rains are over and gone.
Flowers*ln appear on the earth; the*ld season of singing has come, the*ln cooing of doves is*ld heard in our land.
The*ln fig tree forms its early fruit; the*ld blossoming vines spread their fragrance. Arise,*ln come, my darling; my*ld beautiful one, come with me.”
He
My*pn dove in the clefts of the rock, in*ld the hiding places on the mountainside, show*ln me your face, let*ld me hear your voice; for*ln your voice is sweet, and*ld your face is lovely.
Catch*ln for us the foxes, the*ld little foxes that*ln ruin the vineyards, our*ld vineyards that are in bloom.
She
My*pn beloved is mine and I am his; he*ld browses among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks and*ld the shadows flee, turn,*ln my beloved, and*ld be like a gazelle or*ln like a young stag on*ld the rugged hills.
